- A pizza stuffed inside a turkey,

the whole thing deep-fried
and dipped in chocolate!

It's me, the mayor.
- Oh.
Uh, you look different.
Uh, did you get a new haircut?
- Yes, I did.

(brief mellow music)
(record scratches)
- [Babish] This is me.
You're probably wondering how I got here.
Well, it all started about six years ago.

I had started to make a
hobby of filming myself

in the kitchen, food
from movies and the like.

And before I knew it,
I was up to my eyeballs
in requests to stuff a turkey with pizza,
deep fry it, and dip it in chocolate.
Now, I didn't wanna waste an entire turkey

on this wild goose chase, so
I figured I could cut a hole

in a turkey breast and stuff
a slice of pizza inside it.

Now, I'm not sure what
I'm doing with this voice

or what exactly it is I'm
parodying, but I'm telling you,
as I sewed that slice of pizza shut

inside that turkey breast,
carefully lowered it

into some 325 degree
Fahrenheit oil, and cooked it

until the pizza reached
about 160 degrees Fahrenheit,
I knew it was gonna be one crazy summer.
All right, that's enough of that.
You guys just saw all the terrible things
I had to do to this turkey.

Let's get a look at that kind
of upsetting cross section.
Mmm, pepperoni grease. And dig in.
Now, the first thing that I noticed

was that this was a turkey
that had been deep-fried,

stuffed with pizza, and
dipped in chocolate.
So it wasn't terribly good.
I think we can do a whole lot better.

Strewn before me, you can see
a variety of dried chilis:

four or five ancho, pasilla,
and guajillo chilis,

deseeded, destemmed,
torn into little pieces,

and dry-roasted in a hot
pan two to five minutes
or until fragrant, but not smoking.
Then, quench with about two cups of water,
cover, and let steep for about 10 minutes.
You forgetting something, Andy?

That's right, we need
to see with your hands.
Next up, we're toasting some spices
and a whole bunch of other stuff:
three tablespoons sesame seeds,
one teaspoon coriander seed,
1/4 teaspoon black peppercorns,

one teaspoon each dried
cumin, oregano, and thyme,
1/2 teaspoon each chili flakes
and anise seed, and four whole cloves.

Toast it together in a dry pan
for about one to two minutes
or until fragrant, setting aside to cool,
adding a tablespoon of oil to the pot,

and beginning to toast
two small corn tortillas
cut into strips.

Once those are lightly browned
and beginning to crisp,

go ahead and set those aside
to cool with the spices.

Add about two tablespoons
of oil to the pot,

and then we're gonna start
toasting 1/3 cup of peanuts,

fishing those out and
leaving the oil in the pot

so we can toast a whole
bunch of other stuff:

1/3 cup of raw almonds, 1/4 cup
of pepitas or pumpkin seeds,

1/4 cup of black raisins,
and 10 to 12 saltines,
with a couple cinnamon sticks.
It's at this point you're gonna realize

you forgot to tell the
audience what you're making,
and that is mole, the closest thing

to chocolate sauce that
we can put on turkey.

Next up, we got a half dozen
tomatillos, one Roma tomato,

one Spanish onion, and
four cloves of garlic,

variously quartered and
halved, then broiled
until they got some nice color and cooled,
then dumped into a blender,
along with our cooled and drained chilis
and about one cup of their soaking water,
reserving any extra in case more is needed
to thin out the sauce.
Go ahead and give that an initial blend,

mostly just to make room
for all the other stuff
we gotta fit in there, because next up,
we have to add the pile of toasted spices,

nuts, and crackers,
blending the whole thing

until nice and smooth,
utilizing your blender's stuffer
to the fullest extent of the law
and maybe blending in batches.
At this point, you might be wondering,
"Why am I making so much mole?"
And the answer is, it freezes really well.
Next up, before we do anything else,
you can optionally pass your sauce
through a fine mesh sieve.
This will sort out any tooth-breaking bits

of cinnamon stick that
your blender didn't catch.

Back into the pot we go,
along with a nice splash
of stock to loosen things up.

Cover and bring to a simmer
before adding the chocolate,

1 1/2 to 2 discs of Mexican
chocolate, mixing to melt,

and then cooking for about
45 minutes over low heat

until thick and rich
and spiced and complex.
Season with kosher salt,

and there you have it:
our chocolate sauce.
Next up, our pizza stuffing.
I'm gonna start by making a tomato broth

by sauteing together one
clove of crushed garlic
and about 1/2 teaspoon of anchovy paste
for about 30 seconds or until fragrant.
Dump in a 28-ounce can of crushed tomatoes
and 3 1/2 cups of turkey stock.
Add a couple sprigs of fresh rosemary,
cover, and bring to a boil,
simmering for about 30 minutes to an hour.
Then, set aside to cool completely.

Now, since we're doing
mole instead of chocolate,
I thought I'd make our pizza stuffing
a little Mexican-themed as well,
combining one pound of ground pork,
two cloves of minced garlic,
two tablespoons of ancho chili powder,

one tablespoon of paprika,
two teaspoons dried oregano,

one teaspoon kosher salt,
one teaspoon onion powder,

1/2 teaspoon cumin, 1/4
teaspoon ground coriander,
and 1/8 teaspoon ground cinnamon
to make a pound of a sort of quick chorizo
that we're gonna brown in a large skillet,

crushing as we go until all
the crumbles are cooked through

and we've got some nice fond
on the bottom of the pan.

Drain and cool the sausage
on some paper towels.
Then, in the drippings, we're sauteing
four stalks of celery and one large onion,
finely chopped, until lightly caramelized,

letting cool completely before
assembling our stuffing,
combining one loaf of hearty white bread
cut and dried into bite-size croutons,

our sausage, our vegetables,
1/4 cup of chopped parsley,
a tablespoon of fresh minced thyme,
one large, lightly beaten egg,
and a not-insignificant amount
of freshly ground black pepper,

an even more not-insignificant
amount of kosher salt,

and anywhere from two to four
cups of our tomato broth,

starting with about two cups
and adding more as necessary

until the bread is saturated,
but still has its shape.
Then, we're nonstick-ifying a casserole

with some spray oil, dumping
about half the stuffing,

and then I'm going to layer
some torn oaxaca cheese.

If you can't find oaxaca,
mozzarella will do in a pinch.
We're topping up the rest of the stuffing,

some more cheese,
covering and baking at 375

for about 30 minutes or
until cooked through.

Now, for the deep-fried
turkey element of the turkey,
we're going to deep fry a turkey.

I covered how to do this in
a recent episode of "Basics."

Go ahead and click the link
in the upper right hand corner

right now if you wanna
see how to deep fry it.

But needless to say, this
is extremely dangerous.
Do this at your own risk
and only once you know how to do it.

Now, I know that this turkey
is not stuffed with the pizza,

but you can't really deep
fry a turkey with stuffing.
I'd also like to acknowledge
that I'm wearing a decorative sweater,

and that's because I'm in the
middle of shooting a "Botched"

and getting ready to
host our holiday party,
for which we're eating this turkey.

So I'm only gonna be
able to use a little bit
for this experiment.
The rest is getting served.

But let's see how we
did: deep-fried turkey

with pizza stuffing and
chocolate mole sauce.
Now, the mole is delicious,
but it kinda overwhelms the turkey.
That being said, it's got lots and lots
of uses and freezes beautifully.

The real standout here
was the pizza stuffing.

Just don't be like the mayor
about it. Reasonable portions.
